Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Situation2: They are approached by a member facing a difficult life choice and need to give thoughtful guidance.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, my boyfriend’s last words echoing in my mind. Our argument had spiraled out of control, and now he was questioning if we should even stay together. My heart ached, knowing I needed to reach out, to resolve this, to show him I cared enough to fight for us. But just as I was about to call, my phone buzzed again—a message from a church member, desperate for guidance about a life-altering decision. As their pastor, I was expected to offer calm, spiritual wisdom, to be present and steady for them. But how could I give someone else clarity when my own world felt so uncertain? I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me. My boyfriend needed my vulnerability and attention; my congregation needed my strength and faith. I stared at the phone, paralyzed, my heart pulled in two directions, unsure which part of myself to answer first.
